abstract.p: Shawn J Rubel letter replies to Gail Collins's July 7 article deploring the length of the latest Harry Potter book

block.p: It is true, as Gail Collins writes (column, July 7), that we will ''mourn the days'' when Harry Potter ''existed only in books,'' which were ''smaller than breadboxes.''
Yet what does length have to do with a book's magic? Would ''David Copperfield'' be better if it were shorter? Would ''War and Peace''?
It is true, as Gail Collins writes (column, July 7), that we will ''mourn the days'' when Harry Potter ''existed only in books,'' which were ''smaller than breadboxes.''
Yet what does length have to do with a book's magic? Would ''David Copperfield'' be better if it were shorter? Would ''War and Peace''?

When I heard that ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' was going to exceed 700 pages, I was ecstatic for two reasons. First, I love long books. Second, most children are daunted by a book's length. But with Harry Potter, length will not matter, and maybe it will never matter again.
Books should be savored, whatever the length. Here's to hoping that ''Goblet of Fire'' lives up to its predecessors.
SHAWN J. RUBEL New York, July 7, 2000
The writer is marketing manager for Lebhar-Friedman Books.
